'Distribution' of '[[Income in the United States|income]]' in the '[[United
States]]' has been the subject of study by scholars and institutions. Data from
a number of sources the US Department of Commerce, Congressional Budget
Office (CBO), and Internal Revenue Service indicate that income inequality
has grown significantly since the early 1970s,  after several decades of stability.
While inequality has risen among most developed countries, and especially English-
speaking ones, it is highest in the United States. Weeks, J.
(2007). [http://www.un.org/esa/desa/papers/2005/wp6_2005.pdf Inequality Trends
in Some Developed OECD countries]. In J. K. S. & J. Baudot (Ed.), Flat World,
Big Gaps (159â174). New York: ZED Books (published in association with the
United Nations). [http://www.tnr.com/blog/timothy-noah/101648/can-domestic-
policy-affect-income-distribution Can Domestic Policy Affect Income
Distribution?] Timothy Noah| tnr.com| 13 March 2012] *"Among the industrial
democracies where income inequality is increasing, it's much worse in the United
States than it is almost anywhere else. Among 34 nations recently surveyed by
the OECD, the United States got beat only by Turkey, Mexico, and Chile. That's
as measured by the Gini coefficient, and including taxes and government transfer
payments." *note: inequality is higher in less economically developed countries
such as Turkey, Mexico, Chile, which are also members of the OECD

Studies indicate the source of the widening gap (sometimes called the Great
Divergence) has not been gender inequality, which has declined in the US over
the last several decades, [http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/45/42/41527936.pdf Growing
Unequal? Income distribution and poverty in OECD countries (summary)] OECD
(2008) nor inequality between black and white Americans, which has
stagnated during that time, [http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politic-
s/the_great_divergence/features/2010/the_united_states_of_inequality/the_usual_-
suspects_are_innocent.html The United States of Inequality, Entry 2: The Usual
Suspects Are Innocent] By Timothy Noah| slate.com| 6 September 2010 nor
has the gap between the poor and middle class been the major causeâthough it has
grown. [http://www.tnr.com/blog/timothy-noah/100213/whats-so-bad-about-
inequality What's So Bad About Inequality?] Timothy Noah| tnr.com| January 30,
2012 Most of the growth has been between the middle class and top earners,
with the disparity becoming more extreme the further one goes up in the income
distribution. [http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politic-
s/the_great_divergence/features/2010/the_united_states_of_inequality/the_stinki-
ng_rich_and_the_great_divergence.html The United States of Inequality Entry 8:
The Stinking Rich and the Great Divergence]| By: Timothy Noah] Slate.com | 14
September 2010 Upward redistribution of income is responsible for about
43% of the projected Social Security shortfall over the next 75 years. [http://www.cepr.net/index.php/blogs/cepr-blog/the-impact-of-the-
upward-redistribution-of-wage-income-on-social-security-solvency "The Impact of
the Upward Redistribution of Wage Income on Social Security Solvency"] Center
for Economic and Policy Research, 12 February 2013 The Brookings
Institution said in 2013 that income inequality was increasing and becoming
permanent, reducing social mobility in the US.

A 2011 study by the CBO found that the top earning 1 percent of
households gained about 275% after federal taxes and income transfers over a
period between 1979 and 2007, compared to a gain of just under 40% for the 60
percent in the middle of America's income distribution. Other
sources find that the trend has continued since then. [http://www.tnr.com/blog/plank/107174/more-bad-news-the-middle-
class More Bad News For The Middle Class] by Timothy Noah| tnr.com| September
12, 2012 In spite of this data, only 42% of Americans think inequality has
increased in the past ten years. Stiglitz, J.E. (June 14, 2012)
[http://www.salon.com/2012/06/14/weve_been_brainwashed/ "Weâve been
brainwashed"] Salon Income inequality is not uniform among the states; as
measured by the Gini coefficient: after tax income inequality in 2009 was
greatest in Texas and lowest in Maine.

Scholars and others differ as to the causes, solutions, and the significance of
the trend, which in 2011 helped ignite the
"Occupy" protest movement. Education and increased demand for skilled labor are
often cited as causes, some have emphasized the importance of public policy;
others believe the cause(s) of inequality's rise are not well understood. [http://www.cbo.gov/doc.cfm?index=12485 Congressional Budget Office:
Trends in the Distribution of Household Income Between 1979 and 2007]. October
2011. Inequality has been described both as irrelevant in the face of
economic opportunity (or social mobility) in America, and as a cause of the
decline in that opportunity. [http://milescorak.com/2012/01/12/here-is-the-source-for-the-great-
gatsby-curve-in-the-alan-krueger-speech-at-the-center-for-american-progress/
Here is the source for the "Great Gatsby Curve" in the Alan Krueger speech at
the Center for American Progress on January 12] [http://www.tnr.com/blog/timothy-noah/99651/white-house-heres-why-
you-have-care-about-inequality White House: Here's Why You Have To Care About
Inequality] Timothy Noah | tnr.com| January 13, 2012
